Desulfovibrio falkowii is a species of sulfate-reducing bacteria that was first isolated from the sediments of a freshwater lake. It is a Gram-negative, curved-rod shaped bacterium that belongs to the genus Desulfovibrio, which is known for its ability to use sulfate as a terminal electron acceptor during anaerobic respiration.

The cells of D. falkowii are approximately 2-3 μm in length and 0.5-0.8 μm in width, and they are motile due to the presence of a single polar flagellum. The optimum growth temperature for this species is around 30°C, and it can tolerate a pH range of 6.0 to 8.0.

Desulfovibrio falkowii is considered an obligate anaerobe, meaning it can only grow in the absence of oxygen. It derives its energy primarily from the reduction of sulfate to sulfide, using organic compounds as electron donors. This process, known as dissimilatory sulfate reduction, is an important part of the global sulfur cycle and can contribute to the production of hydrogen sulfide in natural environments.

The genome of D. falkowii has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and evolutionary relationships within the Desulfovibrio genus. This species has been the subject of research in various fields, including microbial ecology, bioremediation, and the study of sulfur-cycling processes in aquatic and sedimentary environments.
